questions.stem: When using an acceleration lane to enter a freeway, you should:

choices.text: Match the speed of freeway traffic and merge into a safe gap.
Stop at the end of the ramp and wait for a large gap.
Enter at any speed; freeway traffic must yield.
Signal only after you’ve already merged.

questions.explanation: Use the full acceleration lane to reach the flow speed, signal, and merge into a safe gap without forcing others to brake.

choices.text: Reduce merging conflicts by spacing vehicles entering the freeway.
Measure vehicle speed for tickets.
Indicate a closed freeway.
Allow trucks only.

questions.explanation: Metered ramps release vehicles at intervals to smooth merges and reduce congestion.

questions.stem: The left lane on a multi-lane freeway is typically intended for:

choices.text: Passing and faster-moving traffic.
Trucks only.
Vehicles entering and exiting the freeway.
Vehicles going below the speed limit.

questions.explanation: Left lanes are for passing and faster flow; cruising there without passing can impede traffic.

questions.stem: At 65 mph in ideal conditions, your following distance should be:

choices.text: At least 3–4 seconds.
About 1 second.
Only one car length.
Not needed on freeways.

questions.explanation: High speeds demand more time to react; increase following distance and add more in poor conditions.

questions.stem: Which statement is true about freeway speed?

choices.text: You must obey posted maximums and slow for conditions even if others go faster.
You should always match the fastest vehicle.
It’s safer to drive below the minimum speed in any lane.
Speed limits do not apply in the left lane.

questions.explanation: Drive at a legal, safe speed for conditions; do not exceed posted limits because of the flow.

questions.stem: Before changing lanes on the freeway, you should do all of the following EXCEPT:

choices.text: Signal your intention.
Check mirrors and over-the-shoulder blind spot.
Accelerate quickly without checking traffic behind you.
Complete the maneuver smoothly and cancel your signal.

questions.explanation: Do not accelerate blindly; scanning and blind spot checks are essential.

questions.stem: If you miss your freeway exit, you should:

choices.text: Continue to the next exit.
Back up on the shoulder.
Stop in the gore area and wait.
Make a U-turn across the median.

questions.explanation: Never reverse or stop in travel lanes or gore areas; take the next exit safely.

questions.stem: Your car loses power in a freeway lane. What is the safest first action?

choices.text: Signal, steer right, and aim for the shoulder.
Stop immediately in the lane and walk to the shoulder.
Open your hood in the lane to alert others.
Coast left into the fast lane.

questions.explanation: Signal and move to the right shoulder if possible, then activate hazards and call for help.

questions.stem: California’s Move Over law requires you to:

choices.text: Change lanes away from stopped emergency/roadside vehicles when safe, or slow down.
Stop next to the emergency vehicle to offer help.
Honk and pass normally.
Stay in the same lane at full speed.

questions.explanation: Move over or slow significantly for vehicles with flashing lights on the shoulder when safe.

questions.stem: Which is correct about HOV/express lanes?

choices.text: They have special rules (occupancy/tolls) and specific entry/exit points.
Anyone may enter or exit at any time across double lines.
They are only for emergency vehicles.
They are used only when traffic comes to a stop.

questions.explanation: Obey posted rules and use designated entry/exit zones.

questions.stem: Why is a side-space cushion important on freeways?

choices.text: It gives you room to maneuver away from conflicts.
It reduces fuel use, not safety risk.
It helps other cars draft behind you.
It is required only at night.

questions.explanation: Maintaining space on all sides increases your options to avoid hazards.

questions.stem: The gore area at exits (painted triangle) is intended for:

choices.text: Separation of lanes; you should not drive on or stop there.
Emergency parking only.
A faster shortcut to the exit.
U-turns when you miss your exit.

questions.explanation: Gore areas are not for driving or stopping.
